column1: 65002|~|the logician|~|Let's be clear on what the debate about so called "rape culture" is about. It is not about how we treat victims of rape. We all agree 100% that any victim of rape
column2: including the author of the article
column3: is entitled to a fair hearing and a fair chance to present the evidence of her case. It is also not about the moral significance of rape. We all agree 100% that any sexual act that is initiated by a party A to a party B without the consent of party B is always wrong and merits punishment. There are two points on which people seem to have divergent opinions: (1) The ability of a drunk person to consent (2) The prevalence of rape ==== Concerning (1)
column4: we now show that drunk people have the ability to consent. Proposition: An adult who freely inebriates himself is able to consent to sexual intercourse even in his state of inebriation. (a) Assume
column6: that an adult who freely inebriates himself is not able to consent to sexual intercourse in a state of inebriation. (Assumption) (b) A party P1 who has intercourse with a party P2 in which party P2 has not given consent has raped P2. (Definition of rape). (c) Whenever a husband has intercourse with his drunk wife he does not have her consent. (Follows from a) (d) Whenever a husband has intercourse with his drunk wife he rapes her. (Follows from b and c). (e) It is not the case that whenever a husband has intercourse with his drunk wife that he rapes her. (Self evident) Conclusion: By reductio ad absurdum
column7: it follows from (d) and (e) that (a) is false. Thereby we derive ~(a) which is the proposition. Another way to get to the same conclusion is by thinking about responsibility. (a) A person who inebriates himself voluntarily and commits a crime
column10: part of our legislation) (b) Whenever a person is responsible for his actions
column11: he is expected to make rational decisions about his actions. (Definition of responsibility). (c) If a person is expected to make rational decisions about his actions
column13: that is to say from a policy standpoint
column14: he is considered able to make those rational decisions. (Definition of expectation) (d) A person who inebriates himself voluntarily can make rational decisions about others. (Follows from a
column15: b
column16: and c). (e) If a person can make rational decisions about others he can make them about himself. (Follows from substituting any properties found in an external agent with oneself
column17: also self evident) (f) A person who inebriates himself voluntarily can make rational decisions about himself. (Follows from d
column18: e) (g) Consent to sexual intercourse is a rational decision about oneself. (Definition of consent) Conclusion: The proposition follows from (f) and (g). Also as pointed out in the comments by Concerned '81
column19: the legal system of every state in the union recognizes the ability of freely inebriated individuals to consent. The reasoning here is just to show why. ===== Concerning (2). The other important point in the debate in the comment section is the prevalence of rape and how it should shape our public policy. If rape is as prevalent as some comments suggest -- citing that 1 in 4 or 1 in 5 women will be raped -- then a "rape culture" certainly does exist and we need to allocate proper resources to combat it. However
column20: if rape is as rare as some comments suggests -- as little as less than .1% of women being raped -- then it is disingenuous to claim there is a "rape culture" or a norm of "rape" being acceptable given that it almost never ever takes place. Furthermore
column21: if stats reflect that false rape accusations are much more prevalent than rape
column22: then it is logical to be skeptical of rape claims insofar as skepticism is limited to requiring a burden of proof commensurate to the claim -- as is the case when we adjudicate all cases of civilian misconduct -- and not treating the accusers themselves with scorn or contempt
column23: but ensuring a fair hearing. Proposition: Rape is a very rare occurrence
column24: and thus there is no "rape culture". At the same time
column25: a significant percentage of rape accusations are false. (a) When estimating the prevalence of a phenomenon
column26: a representative sample is preferable to a non-representative sample
column27: all else being equal. (Principles of statistical methods) (b) The FBI data on rape using a large
column28: nationally representative sample
column29: and derives that 53 per 100
column30: 000 females are raped annually which is .053%. ( http://www.fbi.gov/about-us/cj ... (c) The CDC data claiming "1 in 5" women were raped does not use a representative sample but instead one with a small sample and a small response rate of 27.5% that compounds the bias (National Intimate Partner and Sexual Violence Survey 2010:  http://www.cdc.gov/violencepre ...
column31: video on it's flaws for those who don't have time to read it:       Play       Hide          (d) The CDC data has more women being raped than men (1 in 5 vs 1 in 71)
column32: but we know that in the prison population alone
column33: more men are raped than women. (National Intimate Partner and Sexual Violence Survey 2010
column34: Sexual Victimization in Prisons and Jails Reported by Inmates
column35: 2011‚Äì12: National Inmate Survey
column36: 2011‚Äì12). (e) The CDC data contradicts information from a variety of established sources that use large representative samples and have decades of consistent reporting data (Follows from (c) and (d)). (f) The CDC data cannot be trusted. (Follows from (e)). (g) The rate of false rape accusations is about 41% with statistics gathered from a variety of sources including the FBI ("False Rape Allegations" by Eugene Kanin
column37: Archives of Sexual Behavior Feb 1994 v23 n1 p81 (12)
column46: (publication of the U.S. Air Force Office of Special Investigations)
column48: No. 4 ) Conclusion: The proposition follows from ( (b)
column50: and (g) ). ====== Summary: Think carefully. There are matters of fact about the world we live in
column51: and when you have a set of statistics that greatly disagree you have to come to terms with the fact that they cannot both be correct. One has to be right and the other has to be wrong if they disagree about the truth of some proposition at the same time and in the same sense. When you look at all the data on the subject it is incredibly clear that rape is a rare phenomenon and that there must be clear and convincing evidence of rape before anyone accused should be subject to punishment. At the same time
column52: we must be careful to give full support and comfort to any victims of sexual violence. While there is no "rape culture" there is certainly a need to ensure that any victims of rape have the chance to be heard and dealt with fairly. I conclude by saying that justice doesn't come from fabricating statistics
column54: or shaming men as a whole. It comes from seeking out the truth and reasoning about what's best for our society.|~|4|~|Friday

column1: 65002|~|Alcohol and Consent|~|This is where I believe a lot of the confusion enters the conversation. Everyone believes violent forcible rapists are deserving of the harshest possible punishment. But when the alcohol consumption vs. consent issue becomes involved there's a great deal of debate
column2: often because it is difficult for either party to know how intoxicated the other party is. Certainly the scenario you propose is rape
column3: plain and simple. But there are grey areas that make people uncomfortable
column4: because of the possibilities for misunderstandings that lead to highly severe consequences. It's a tough question. But the alcohol consumption vs. consent issue seems to be at the crux of the disagreements here. The University sets much stricter standards for the level of alcohol that must be consumed to vitiate consent than the state does. Is this a good or a bad thing? I don't know. I know rape is a huge societal issue I know sexual assault is a massive problem. And I know the alcohol-fueled culture of sex on any college campus makes for complex scenarios that rarely fit the "sex on a Saturday night" stereotype.|~|0|~|Thursday

column1: 64968|~|'04|~|The more I listen to these stories the more I think that victims might benefit from good legal representation.  I was sexually harassed pretty badly just out of grad school
column2: and a big reason my abuser mostly got away with it was her more sophisticated understanding of the system and my shock.  Hiring a lawyer would have also given me more credibility both as a victim and as a threat
column3: which is exactly what I was--a threat to illegitimate power.  Fortunately
column4: I also had some exposure to lawyers after graduation
column5: so I was very meticulous about documenting the harassment
column6: which proved to be very useful.  As an undergrad
column7: there's no way I would have known that and even if I had been John Roberts
column8: I think representing myself in the wake of trauma would have been extremely difficult.  A lawyer can help you navigate your options in the criminal justice and civil systems and against your attacker or the school. So
column9: advice from an alum: hire a lawyer. If you can't afford one try to get legal aid or pro bono help.  Women's groups should reach out to alums to establish a legal defense fund if necessary.|~|14|~|Tuesday
column10: May 6

column1: 64968|~|Space Monkey|~|This is my question every time I hear one of these stories: where is the legal process? Where are the police? Where is the victim's lawyer?|~|1|~|Wednesday
column2: May 7

column1: 64968|~|'04|~|Those are really good questions.  In my sexual harassment case
column2: I was initially reluctant to hire a lawyer for several reasons.  First
column4: my work with my harasser before she crossed the line was very intense and involved a lot of confidential information.  So when she violated my trust
column5: it was shocking: everything took on a confusing double meaning
column6: and all options jeopardized my work--a true double bind.  Second
column7: I was either in denial or naive about her character
column8: and I thought I could work things out between us.  Third
column9: I didn't know what to expect from a lawyer
column10: and the last thing I wanted at the time was a big
column11: new experience that involved telling personal material to strangers.  And forth
column12: I didn't realize the way in which I had been dragged into what was not only a professional and psychological dilemma but also a legal one. What I wish I had realized then was that: my harasser had crossed a line of decency and common sense severe enough to be a crime against the community.  That is
column13: she had violated a public trust that couldn't be restored by anything she said or did to me.   Not that she ever made amends even when given multiple chances.  Some people you just can't work with.  Furthermore
column14: shielding her from the consequences of her behavior did no one a favor--not me
column15: not others in the organization
column16: and not even her.  Sometimes
column17: the best thing you can do for someone is to tell hard truths and/or punish their behavior.  Tough love from a safe distance.  Secondly
column18: that all this drama could be translated into the concrete language of the legal system where I could offload a good deal of shame and perceived responsibility that felt imposed upon me.  Also
column19: that had I chosen to file a civil suit
column20: my lawyer would have received a portion of the damages
column21: and I wouldn't have had to pay him or her.  Also
column22: that I would have had an empowering degree of control over my legal options and wouldn't have had to be maximally punitive. Of course
column23: every case is individual; I was lucky enough to be able to change jobs; rape is more severe than harassment
column24: and harassment invokes labor law.  But the principles of injury through negligence and wrongdoing seem pretty similar to me.  I mean if a contractor threw a brick off the Frist Center at you
column25: broke your shoulder
column26: and refused to pick up your medical bills most adults wouldn't hesitant to consult a lawyer.  Why should a more intense crime like rape be any different?  No one is born knowing how to be a champion victim
column27: but a good lawyer can help you there... legally
column28: at least.  Likewise
column29: for good therapists
column30: religious or philosophical leaders
column32: etc. in other ways.  Of course
column33: no one is morally responsible for crimes committed against them.  This comment is simply addressed to victims because I believe they might listen to someone who has been in a less intense but similar situation. P.S.  The best thing I did with my harasser was to warn her off when things got weird then send her an email summarizing our conversation
column35: but when you did X
column37: never do X again.  I look forward to a excellent professional relationship with you going forward."  (If necessary you can add
column38: "if X or other sexually suggestive comments persist
column41: or C.")  Later when she ignored it
column42: I then had written proof that her conduct was explicitly "unwelcome" in legal terms.  Of course
column43: this technique only works in a pre-existing relationship going off the tracks.|~|3|~|Wednesday

column2: i wish that there was a paragraph afterwards that reiterated how any clothing choices or level of intoxication do not justify or warrant a sexual assault. rather

column1: 64338|~|'15|~|Maybe if you weren't a freshman
column2: you'd understand that writing seminar imparts a way of thinking that is critical and universal
column3: applicable to just about any course you're going to take. Any rigorous standardization of "skills" that are taught would result in an even narrower focus of the seminars. That is
column4: one could learn elements of style consistent with one field that is entirely inapplicable to other fields. Within the current system
column5: the seminars teach a way of thinking that transcends the nuances of writing within any particular discipline. The ability to situate yourself with respect to other scholars within any given field and develop a logical
column6: consistent argument is found in any field - even in the sciences. As a science major who has taken his share of humanities and social science classes
column7: I can say that the way of thinking taught by the writing seminars shaped my writing in each of those distinct areas.|~|11|~|Tuesday

column1: 64338|~|16|~|So writing sem did absolutely nothing for you in terms of orienting you to writing or thinking in a certain way? At least for me

column1: 64338|~|'13|~|I think this column hits upon some of my troubles with writing sem. However
column2: I think my worries about writing seminar lie in the ability to improve the writing abilities of all students. I spoke with my own writing seminar professor (lecturer?) and others
column3: and they said they struggled in the class to strike a balance in how much "writing" to teach. Some of the students in their class already wrote at a college (and Princeton) level
column4: while some were years behind. No fault at all of the students
column5: but the teachers with whom I spoke found it difficult to teach enough writing basics to those who needed help while still engaging those who had learned college-level writing in high school. Office hours helped
column7: but they still never found enough time to help the less fluent writers in the classes. This difficult balance may be one reason why some writing seminars tend to focus more on the subject matter than the act of writing.|~|2|~|Wednesday

column1: 64338|~|McGrin|~|A generation ago
column2: Princeton's writing program used to emphasize research skills
column4: and literary analysis. It also used to hire professional nonfiction writers as instructors. I still bless my Lit 151 instructor for all her wise coaching and stimulating
column5: practical advice on how to make my prose direct
column7: and informed. West College killed this model of writing instruction long
column10: it was great.|~|2|~|Wednesday
column11: April 30

column1: 64185|~|anon|~|Language classes are tiny. Maybe Mr. Sagiv doesn't quite realize this
column2: since he seems not to have taken one here. I'm in an introductory language class right now for a less-popular language-- we have three people in our class. It's great. If we had more people in our class who weren't dedicated to doing the work or showing up half the time
column3: then they'd be slowing the rest of us down. It's hard work keeping up with a 101/102 language course if you haven't studied that language before. And if you're not keeping up with the work
column4: you're going to force the class to spend more time reviewing old concepts
column5: wasting the time of the other students. This isn't an issue in big lecture classes with little to no interaction among students or between students and teachers. If you don't pay attention one week in ECO100
column6: you're only screwing yourself. If you don't pay attention one week in (language)101
column7: you're screwing everyone. If you're serious about learning a language at Princeton
column8: you'll make time for taking it for a grade. If you're not serious about learning a language
column10: just stay out of the classes and don't slow down the people who are serious. Grab an "Intro to" or "Teach Yourself" book from Firestone or Labyrinth instead. Or do some sort of course over the summer when you might have more time.|~|6|~|Tuesday
column11: April 29

column1: 64185|~|'14|~|I think a better solution would be to get rid of grade deflation for introductory language courses. It  creates such ridiculous curves in these courses that we're effectively punishing AB students who didn't have the opportunity to do AP language in high school and basically has the consequence of punishing students from low income areas.|~|5|~|Tuesday
column2: April 29

column1: 64185|~|noaudit|~|I understand the argument in favor of allowing PDF. By why audit? Auditing students rarely contribute to the class and usually drop out without learning much. And having an audit appear on  a transcript is worthless.|~|2|~|Tuesday
column2: April 29

column1: 64185|~|alumna|~|Learning a language is all about commitment. It's not something you can do from time to time
column2: you need to immerse yourself. That's why 101/102 language classes are scheduled 5 times a week. If you expect to be able to speak a language fluently after 2-3 years worth of classes
column4: not 50% (even if giving 100% might only get you a B+). I doubt the author would like to take Chinese for a year on pass/fail and then discover he can't keep up with the conversations or understand what the instructor is saying in class if he decides to take the second year classes. Language classes rapidly move from instruction in English to instruction in the language of choice. Taking a language class pass/fail might prove disastrous for the student's future prospects of studying the language. Doing work to barely pass the class can only lead to embarrassment when the student won't have the slightest clue of what's going on and might not even understand the instructions on an exam (especially for Asian languages). There's a reason why language classes require close to 100% attendance. The author should speak after he has a clue how college language classes work. I took three years of Japanese at Princeton and I can say that experience is definitely one of the highlights of my Princeton years. But had I not given close to 90-100% I would most certainly have been forced to quit studying the language after a year (or less) from embarrassment at slowing down everyone else taking the class if nothing else.|~|0|~|Sunday

column6: CPS staff work closely with the Office of the Dean of Undergraduate Students and the Graduate School to figure out the right algorithm of student support
column7: which may include a reduced course load
column8: extensions on assignments and a care plan that supports the student‚Äôs resumption of studies." But then how do you explain away what happened to this student? (LINK:  http://dailyprincetonian.com/n...  He had the support of his psychiatrist
column9: who said it was "in his best interest" to REMAIN at Princeton
column10: the support of his professors
column11: with whom he had worked out a plan to pass ALL his classes even after a three week break. He TRIED to get a reduced course load
column12: but Princeton denied him. He OFFERED to live with his mom off-campus
column13: but Princeton banned him altogether
column14: until he was forced to withdraw because he had missed too many classes (that he wasn't allowed to attend.) And that's only the beginning. This doesn't follow with the picture that Dr. Chin painted for us above. Until CPS and the Princeton administration can explain this self-contradiction
column15: I will continue to advocate for policy changes on behalf of the scared and silent students with more severe mental health struggles... because in this battle

column1: 63793|~|AIS|~|I really appreciate Dr. Chin's reasoned
column2: compassionate response to the concerns being raised in our community about mental health care.  Having worked with  therapists at CPS
column3: I know they are caring and absolutely have the well-being of students at the fore.  Students are told during the first appointment what the limits of confidentiality are. Having worked with therapists in private practice as well
column4: it seems to me that the standards of confidentiality are the same regardless of the setting. Also
column5: these discussions highlight to me the differential attitudes towards psychological vs. medical care and recommendations in our society. Why are we more willing to make solo treatment decisions
column7: about our mental health in a way we probably wouldn't about other physical health concerns? To me
column8: one of the issues is not whether someone could conceivably do well in courses while dealing with severe mental health concerns
column10: we need to take time to focus on our health and well-being rather than sucking it up and forcing ourselves to get through a semester. I know this idea might be anathema to some but I believe it teaches the important life-lesson of self-care and is a sign of strength not weakness.  Self-care being another idea that may be foreign in our "work hard
column11: play hard" Princeton culture.|~|3|~|Friday

column1: 63793|~|There's more at stake|~|These discussions haven't been focused on the simple question of whether or not people want to make 'solo treatment decisions' regarding their health care. Instead
column2: they've been about the discrimination inherent in Princeton's current policies. When the rubber hits the road
column3: students with physical health concerns are *allowed* to make decisions. Students with mental health concerns are NOT. This is the problem.|~|2|~|Friday

column1: 63793|~|guinness blaine|~|I could have easily taken this year off for health reasons

column1: 63793|~|sec|~|I feel very fortunate to have such a broad range of mental health services available to me from CPS.  This is an extremely stressful time and it is comforting to know that CPS is there for me whenever I need help.  I do trust that my CPS visits are confidential.  CPS is not allowed to release information regarding contact with a student without permission from the student except when the safety of the student or others may be deemed at risk.  I support this stance for the overall benefit and safety of the total university population.  In the same regard
column2: I do believe that CPS is always first and foremost acting in the best interest of the student despite some opinions to the contrary.  CPS is a tremendous resource to our student body and I would hate for some naysayers to dissuade students from seeking the help they need due to misinformation.  CPS is a comprehensive university resource that we all should take advantage of in our times of need.|~|2|~|Monday

column17: (3) Students can't be forced to involuntarily withdraw if they are a danger to themselves. This would require that they are a danger to *others*
column18: according to the new "direct threat" regulation in Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act. LINK:  http://www.ada.gov/taman2.html OTHER LINK:  http://www.calstate.edu/gc/doc...  (this one is slightly more readable.)|~|7|~|Thursday

column1: 62987|~|Q|~|Thank you for writing the words a lot of us don't know how to verbalize
column2: even when we're screaming them in our heads. Although I ultimately chose not to take a year off
column3: there was a point in my Princeton career when I would wake up and wish I hadn't; when I would cross the street and wish a car would take the choice out of my hands; when I'd open the screen of the bathroom window and wonder what would happen if I just leaned out a couple more inches. Although I was seeing a counselor at CPS regularly
column4: I never once verbalized these thoughts. I couldn't afford a therapist in the community
column5: and so I carefully analyzed every sentence before I spoke it out loud. Every time a CPS person would ask a seemingly innocuous question ("Have you thought about hurting yourself recently; Is there anything more you'd like to say") I'd vigorously shake my head
column7: and say: "Of course I don't think about those things. I'm not like that." But I was like that. Eventually I found my own form of self-therapy
column8: not through drugs or CPS. I was lucky that my mind began to heal itself
column9: and I recovered. Depression is an illness
column10: not a bad choice we make. Making us fear asking for help is like making us fear telling the doctor about a lump we found. It physically pains me to think about the students here who fear to say those few words. I would personally be their confidante
column11: but we don't even have a student group for that. We have anonymous peers at SHARE
column12: but we don't have peers we can tell our most life-threatening problems to. Like sexual harassment/assault
column13: depression is not at the fault of the victim. I will be ashamed of to say I attend this university if they continue to ignore a problem they have perpetuated.|~|28|~|Monday

column1: 62987|~|'16|~|I'm currently on gap year for similar reasons
column2: though my mental health situation was no where near as severe as yours. And while I was already aware of the gap year/readmissions process bc I mean
column4: your article reminded me of something that's really disturbing: I was able to be completely honest during my treatment and not really worry about the implications for my readmission because my symptoms weren't severe enough to pose a "liability" to the university in the first place. I was already struggling a lot and clearly needed help
column5: but I wasn't suicidal nor did I ever want to self-harm
column6: and that might've made all the difference in the way I was treated during my withdrawal (my dean was SUPER helpful and supportive
column7: but if I had been less stable
column8: would she have been?). The fact that there are people out there who are in an even worse condition than I was and are unable/afraid of getting help BECAUSE they're in a worse condition is really twisted. Like
column9: the fact that one of my first reactions to discovering I had depression was "Well
column10: at least I'm not suicidal because then getting back into school would be a LOT harder" says a LOT about what Princeton's mental health system does to us. In addition to its mental health policies
column11: I think another thing that needs to change about Princeton is the stigma surrounding taking time off. Obviously the university shouldn't force anyone to do anything
column12: but time off shouldn't be seen by students as such a dire option in the first place. I didn't consider taking time off until my dean recommended it
column13: and while I at first refused
column14: when I did decide to take time off a few weeks later it ended up being the best decision I made here. While I of course understand being afraid of having to withdraw permanently
column15: I hear about people who are afraid of having to withdraw even for a year
column16: and I think that's a little weird considering the alternative is remaining miserable at a place that will only make you more miserable if you don't get help. Ever since I withdrew and was open about my withdrawal
column17: I've had people who're considering doing the same come to me for advice they're afraid of asking their friends
column18: and people who went on leave of absence after I did have come to me for support that they don't get from friends who don't understand
column19: and that's really saddening to me. When you're dealing with mental health issues
column20: leaving Princeton for a bit can be one of the best/healthiest things you can do
column21: and people shouldn't be so intimidated by it.|~|15|~|Monday
column22: April 21

column1: 62987|~|Author|~|Hey! Author here.... Thanks so
column2: so much for your thoughtful comment. I absolutely agree that time off doesn't need to be as scary as it may seem. I was never scared of time off itself
column3: only that I might be forced (or at least
column4: extremely pressured) to make that decision before I was ready to/before I had come to terms with it. I think one of the most frightening aspects of 'time off' for people struggling with mental health is that it removes them from their base of support. That was the number one consideration making me hesitant to leave Princeton... my counselor
column6: my mentors--they were all here. Not at home. But I made the decision to take a leave of absence anyway
column7: and my fears about leaving my support system were assuaged by my ability to really think things through
column9: with my parents and friends. It was especially helpful that I didn't have to worry about pressure from the administration. If I'd been forced to leave before I was really ready to do so
column10: I'm certain that it would have actually made things worse for me. And for this reason
column11: if I were given the opportunity make the choice again
column12: I would still choose to avoid CPS. Even if they thought time off was better for me in the long run
column13: the short term distress of being forced to leave my friends too early could have sent me over the edge. And to anyone who might be reading this
column14: I want you to know that taking a year off does have the potential to be the best decision you could make. It certainly was for me. Because I took the year off
column15: I was able to attend an Intensive Outpatient Program close to home
column16: and it had a tremendous impact on my recovery. This IOP consisted of three hours of treatment
column17: five days a week; it would have been impossible to do a program this thorough if I had remained at Princeton. '16
column18: back to what you said
column19: I've also had my friends come to me for support and advice about taking time off
column20: and it IS sad that these students don't feel comfortable speaking to their deans or to CPS about the same questions. I really
column21: REALLY hope that this column can help instigate change in Princeton's mental health policy
column22: for the good of the students and the university. That's my goal. And also
column23: a big THANK YOU to everyone else who has commented on this article with their words of support. You've been a huge source of encouragement for me :)|~|12|~|Tuesday

column1: 62987|~|Briana Wilcox|~|I also went to CPS often for my freshman and sophomore years
column2: and I also self-censored during therapy because I knew better than to admit impulses to self-harm. Instead of scratching myself with a pen cap
column3: I would ink/carve messages of support into my own arms and wear long sleeves. Instead of crashing my bike
column4: I would sit on a rooftop accessible to my dorm window and wonder whether three stories was high enough to do the job. I also feared taking time off; a whole year of nothing to do but think- about my nightmares
column6: my failure to even be a "normal" college student- would have been its own hell. At least at school I had extracurriculars and friends to distract me.  In my experience
column7: taking time off was essentially an admission of weakness and inadequacy. I would finally be admitting that I did not belong at Princeton
column9: and would never be. I wasn't in a healthy enough state to wrestle with that
column10: so I opted to lie and continue dragging myself through 4 consecutive years. Now that I'm out
column11: I'm so much happier
column12: and I find myself referring to my time at Princeton as "serving time" whenever anyone asks about my ritzy degree. I was one of the lucky ones who found other ways to cope: I befriended good people
column13: I took smaller
column14: upper-division classes
column15: I stopped caring whether I was "the best" or "good enough"
column16: and I fell into the best relationship I've ever had in one of the best people I've ever met. They all worked to save my life
column17: and I am grateful. I can't even imagine what life would be like for the unlucky. Princeton habitually fails people like me and lies about it. I don't understand why. I just know that I'm not donating a single cent until they actually comply with Title IX (wrt addressing sexual assault
column18: gender-based harassment
column19: and LGBT hate crimes) and make meaningful change to support students' mental health
column20: not destroy it.  I was fine before I went to Princeton. Since leaving Princeton
column21: I've continued struggling to recover from my experiences there and trying not to let it limit my options moving forward. Who knows
column22: maybe I'll be one of the lucky ones.|~|3|~|Wednesday

column1: 62987|~|Tired|~|Any mental health care professional worth their salt would NEVER disclose any specifics of therapy to a University regardless of any waiver you sign.  They will say
column2: "Yes person X is doing well and can handle school" or they will say
column5: this person should not be under pressure at school."  They won't say
column6: "Jimmy told me about this time he thought about crashing his bike into the stairs."  It just doesn't work that way.  No one should be afraid to seek help from a professional because you are worried the university will find out about it and somehow use this against you.  Likewise
column7: no one should lie in therapy or withhold because you think it will get back to the university.  I get the fear and I get why you might be worried about what you say.  But therapy won't do you any good if you don't trust your therapist.  If you don't believe me
column8: ask them flat out.  Ask them what they will or won't do and whether or not you can trust them.  It's a meaningful conversation to have and might help put you at ease.|~|2|~|Wednesday

column1: 62987|~|Chiming in|~|I'm part of a comment thread on the April 23rd response letter that addressed some of your questions
column2: so I want to chime in here with some relevant details. Regarding whether health care professionals can choose to reveal nothing other than their opinion... that's not entirely true
column3: unfortunately. It's not just a discussion over the phone
column4: for instance. I decided to try to look into the required "Questions for Treatment Providers" form that was briefly mentioned in the letter to the author (above)
column5: but could only find it in some public records of the lawsuit that's happening with that other Princeton student who was banned from campus. (It's interesting that this form can't be found on the internet... almost as if Princeton doesn't want the world to know that this form exists.) The form itself isn't shown in this document
column6: but if you go to item 22 on page 6
column7: you can see a description of what's in it: "It requires the provider to indicate the dates and type of treatment provided; the medications prescribed; a description of the focus and type of treatment
column9: the patient‚Äôs presenting concerns and the efficacy of treatment in addressing them
column10: the diagnostic assessment and impressions; an evaluation of whether the patient‚Äôs functioning has in the past or is currently compromised by a host of mental health impairments; an assessment of the patient‚Äôs readiness to return to school
column11: remaining 'functional difficulties or impairments' and whether those impairments would 'contraindicate or make more difficult a return to a high-stress academic environment.' [...]"  etc.... LINK:  http://www.bazelon.org/LinkCli... This is definitely more in-depth than a simple "yes" or "no." (My favorite part of that form is that it uses the word "contraindicate"--that's so quintessentially Princeton

column1: 62987|~|baccarat|~|"YOU LIED"? Oh that is just hilarious. Utterly rich. I'm chortling. Here's a helpful hint: everybody lies. You're "lying" by concealing your name on a public forum while attacking someone who has gone out of their way to tell their story. You seem to want to punish everyone but yourself for this sin of lying. If I didn't know for sure
column2: I'd think that you were projecting. In medicine
column3: we know people lie all the time. It's just a fact of life. You can't punish everyone for lying. Neither should Princeton. Neither should you. Mental illness is not like a cold or broken bone. You might never truly recover from the damage. It can take years. Even when you are stable enough to begin work
column4: you will struggle. Self-acceptance and external support allows you to rebuild your world. What is important is that the person thinks that they are ready to go back. My sib had a series of medical problems requiring surgery that distracted him while attending UCLA. He decided to take a year out. He's now working as a software developer at a major corporation
column5: building up his confidence to return to UCLA. Thankfully UCLA believes in your record and milestones instead of requiring you to sign away your rights to patient-doctor confidentiality.|~|5|~|Monday

column1: 62987|~|ala|~|Exactly right
column2: Anonymous Guy. It's hilarious that GoodluckGirl thinks that mental health professionals who violate doctor-patient confidentiality (because of the university's liability-driven policies) deserve the trust and honesty of students. This is Princeton...everyone going to CPS is smart enough to LOGICALLY withhold information if/when it will be abused and used against them - that is not some 20 year old ploy to manipulate and it's not just a result of this individual's "condition." I didn't find this article to be fear driven
column3: and obviously the author is not alone (check out the citations and many comments from others who have experienced the same - i.e. the student who got kicked off campus just because he WAS COMPLETELY HONEST about his suicide attempt...but his psychiatrist and professors supported him and stated he was well enough to cope/recover and stay on campus...he got kicked off campus anyway by the administration. Just one example of the university using HONESTY against students). "Either get better or cope with uncertainty better" - just wow. Those kinds of directives are really helpful *sarcasm*...but seriously
column4: statements like that have an implied assumption that mental health patients can just flip a switch to get better
column5: and are completely unfair and harsh.|~|18|~|Monday

column2: I'm sorry
column3: but I must offer a dissenting opinion. It is very important for CPS and UHS to know the status of your mental and physical health. It is unfortunate that it is invasive
column4: and I'm truly sorry if that contributes negatively to your experience
column5: but Princeton is not a place where you should be simultaneously battling an onslaught of work as well as suicidal tendencies. This place is a pressure cooker. It seems harsh for them to strongly urge a leave of absence
column6: but that is in all honesty the most sensible response to those feelings. Mental rehabilitation takes time and patience. I nonetheless think it's important that the University places a lot of value on the mental health of its students. And yes
column7: asking a suicidal student to take time off is the best advice the University could give.|~|1|~|Monday

column1: 62987|~|Dissenting to the dissent|~|Why do people keep referring to Princeton as a pressure cooker? Whenever someone does that
column2: it ends up portraying people who suffer from mental health as simply "the ones who couldn't withstand the pressure." Not only is that severely reductionist (because it ignores the role of biological aspects)
column3: but it's also a huge part of what contributes to the stigma. (Students are afraid of being perceived as "not strong enough" emotionally/mentally) Also
column4: you keep saying the University is "strongly urging" students to leave or giving "advice" to take time off
column5: but that's not what students are worried about. They're worried about when the university FORCES them to leave
column6: regardless of what's actually best for them. Consider
column8: the student who only has health insurance through the university
column9: who can't see a psychologist or psychiatrist unless they're on campus and whose treatment would be cut off if they have to go home. (But Princeton doesn't care.) Or
column10: consider the student whose problems stem from broken family relationships
column11: and for whom being sent back home could be the worst thing to happen for their mental and emotional well-being. (But Princeton doesn't care.) And what about the student who was actively seeking help
column12: and had support from both his long-term psychiatrist and his professors? (But Princeton didn't care
column13: and banned him from campus anyway.) Listen
column14: I'm not saying that time off really is the best plan for most students. But sometimes
column15: it's the worst plan. And even if that's only the case for maybe one or two students a year
column16: the fact that Princeton forces them to leave anyway is what's causing people to fear CPS
column17: and subsequently this is why the campus is becoming an increasingly dangerous environment for students with severe mental health issues. And THIS is why change is imperative. Sorry if it feels like I singled you out
column18: '15. I'm really just upset about the situation in general and the fact that people keep (accidentally) perpetuating the stigma by reducing the situation to nothing more than Princeton being a "pressure cooker." Each individual situation is unique
column19: and almost every single one is far more complicated than the student falling under the weight of pressure.|~|1|~|Monday

column1: 62987|~|Anonymous|~|I'm grateful this important and powerful column was published. It's so true that students fear going to CPS with their most serious mental health issues--last year I was one of them. On one particularly bad night
column2: I was having severe self-harm thoughts
column3: but neither of the two friends I had tried to call picked up. As a last resort
column4: I tried to call the national suicide hotline
column5: thinking that speaking with a stranger would be better than speaking with no one at all. But after a couple rings
column6: an automated voice started to say
column7: "please wait while we transfer you to a nearby..." and I freaked out. I hung up immediately
column8: thinking that if they knew where I was (in order to let me talk to a nearby crisis center)
column9: they might come and get me. And then
column10: if the people at the crisis center came and got me
column11: I was sure that Princeton would kick me out
column12: just as they had for several other students who went to the hospital for suicidal thoughts or attempts. Fortunately
column13: I tried one of my friends again
column14: and this time they picked up... but it definitely left me rattled to realize I couldn't even call an "anonymous" hotline for fear that I'd have to leave campus. Someone might think that it was "irrational" for me to assume that Princeton would force me to withdraw if they found out about my phonecall. After all
column15: that only happened to a few people... But tell me
column16: is a student in a situation like this really thinking rationally? When it comes down to life or death
column17: students need to be able to trust the university. I didn't trust them
column18: but I was lucky enough to have friends who pick up their phones at 3am. Not everyone is so lucky
column19: though.|~|1|~|Sunday

column1: 62684|~|Dean  Bogucki|~|Our curriculum focuses on the fundamentals of engineering
column2: with an aim of educating students for a career
column3: rather than training for a first job.  This focus on the principles of engineering is perhaps the genesis of the things the author has heard about Princeton engineering
column4: since we start from the principles and then move to the applications
column5: rather than the other way around.  There's nothing theoretical about these principles:  the laws of thermodynamics
column7: can't be repealed.  We also educate students with broad interests
column8: who take full advantage of the liberal arts setting here at Princeton.  This has proven to be an effective approach
column9: as our alumni have generally been quite successful as leaders in many different fields.   Adding applied courses in freshman year would displace the humanities and social science electives that most BSE students came to Princeton to take. I'm not sure where the author has gotten the idea that attrition from the BSE program is increasing.  In fact
column10: there is a steady stream of freshman and sophomore AB students into the BSE program
column11: which offsets the number of students who switch to AB.    Here is a fact:  we began with 331 BSE students in the Class of 2017 in September.   As of today
column12: there are 321.    Some more will leave by the end of sophomore year
column13: which is natural
column14: but certainly not to the degree that the author asserts. If any reader has questions about the BSE program
column15: please feel free to contact me.    --Dean Peter Bogucki
column16: associate dean for undergraduate affairs

column1: 62684|~|Andrew Houck|~|The author‚Äôs main hypothesis ‚Äì that the structure of Princeton‚Äôs engineering curriculum biases students towards non-technical jobs ‚Äì is intriguing
column2: but does not seems to be born out by fact.  A cursory glance at career statistics for our peer institutions shows that their student career choices mirror our own (for instance
column3: 12% of MIT students go into finance
column4: 12% into consulting).  A significant fraction of engineering students at all top schools pursue finance jobs
column5: not because they are bored of engineering
column6: but because they are highly sought-after
column9: enjoy the work and environment. Putting that aside
column10: many faculty empathize with the author‚Äôs desire for more hand-on learning in early stages of engineering education
column11: and this is reflected in ongoing changes brought about by SEAS
column13: and the various engineering departments.  As departmental representative for ELE
column14: I am most familiar with the changes going on in electrical engineering.  We have always been quite strong at engaging students in faculty research
column15: but we want to make sure we do more than churn out faculty clones (though really
column16: can there ever be too many of me??).  As such
column17: one of our main strategic goals is to better serve students interested in more applied engineering. To this end
column18: we have recently revamped all of our required courses
column19: making sure that there is a significant lab component to get students hand-on experience starting in sophomore year.  These are not typical one-off three-hour labs
column20: but rather ongoing projects throughout the semester where students build significant and complex systems
column21: learning fundamentals in a more applied way.  We have added sophomore level independent work courses
column22: so students can do independent work for credit starting in sophomore year.  We‚Äôve given students significantly more freedom in CarLab to pursue independent ideas.   We are supporting the hardware side of Hack Princeton in order to foster a culture of engineering outside the classroom.  We are now requiring a senior thesis
column23: and are working hard to make sure that this will be an amazing and defining experience.  We are encouraging students to pursue their own project ideas for their thesis
column24: including in groups and across departmental boundaries where appropriate
column25: and are matching them with faculty members who are excited to mentor students outside their main research area. We are also lucky enough to have generous alumni who enable incredible new initiatives.  Thanks to the Steve Johnson Slingshot Fund
column26: we can offer significant resources to ELE students to pursue entrepreneurial projects or truly unique internship opportunities ‚Äì we‚Äôve so far offered money for a group of students developing an Android-controlled power strip
column27: another building a new type of 3D touchscreen
column28: another creating a network of e-ink based campus posters
column29: and to send a student to NASA.  We‚Äôre also building ‚Äúnerd kits‚Äù for incoming students that include all of the hardware platforms they will use during their required courses
column30: as well as some cool sensors and actuators; they keep these throughout their time here
column31: so they always have access to a variety of new technologies
column32: lowering the bar for tinkering. In short
column33: although I‚Äôm not sure it will sway people‚Äôs career paths
column34: you‚Äôve touched on something very important to us
column35: and something that will significantly enhance our student‚Äôs educational experience. Princeton will never give up on teaching strong fundamentals ‚Äì the strength of our student‚Äôs on fundamentals is perhaps the most frequent compliment I hear from employers ‚Äì but that doesn‚Äôt mean we can‚Äôt also engage at a more applied level as well.|~|11|~|Thursday

column1: 62684|~|hlz '14|~|I'd like to add that even if the curriculum remains theory-first
column2: which (in theory) isn't a bad idea
column3: it would be nice to have more support from the University for applied engineering as extracurricular activities. For example
column5: a lot of MIT's culture of building things exists outside of classes
column6: ranging from makerspaces (MITERS) to more formally organized programs (like Formula SAE). Over the last couple years Princeton hackathons have begun introducing hardware hacking
column7: but attendance and focus is still largely CS/coding based with increasing participation by EE/MAE/etc. PAVE doesn't seem to be doing all that much at the moment
column8: and it's incredibly difficult to acquire funding for engineering projects like Formula SAE (or Formula SAE Electric
column9: which we attempted to start several times) due to immense difficulty acquiring funding and space to work. I think that's generally true for a lot of applied engineering projects that aren't code: you need money
column10: tools
column11: and space to work
column12: and a lot of cool projects get expensive very quickly. The University is in a good position to help out with this sort of thing
column13: and in funding and supporting
column14: for example
column15: a Formula SAE team
column16: it would be joining MIT
column17: Georgia Tech
column18: UM
column19: McGill
column20: Columbia
column21: etc. -- a lot of top engineering schools who are able to attract enthusiastic
column22: hands-on engineers and teach them the fundamentals while giving them plenty of real world engineering opportunities. Basically
column23: making things in CS is cheap - you need a working computer and internet
column24: and you can build what you want. Most of engineering isn't like that
column25: and students would really benefit from more University support for hands-on projects outside of class
column26: which seems like a good way to generate enthusiasm for engineering while still keeping the curriculum theory-focused.|~|5|~|Thursday
column27: April 17

column1: 62684|~|anon|~|We actually have a MakerSpace
column2: though.|~|1|~|Thursday
we have a Makers Collective
column4: and it would be disingenuous to say that it's a major part of our engineering culture given that it's barely open at the moment. (I hope it grows and does awesomely in the future
column5: but right now it's in its infancy -- if any readers are interested they should get involved!) HLZ's main point -- that there's little institutional support for outside building-things projects -- still stands. I would also love to see more building-things outside of classes. Best of both worlds and all that.|~|1|~|Thursday

column1: 62684|~|'16|~|I don't believe this is a problem with the SEAS as a whole. I also don't think anybody would suggest the SEAS should introduce such broad policies as placing more requirements upon BSE freshmen to take more applied engineering courses before they've declared a major
column2: or trying to create some required general applied engineering classes that all BSE freshmen must take. The engineering departments are too varied. Good engineering courses which emphasize applications exist in every engineering department
column3: and in part it's up to students to seek them out. I think it's reasonable to suggest that BSE freshmen should take more of these engineering classes if they can. Perhaps a couple departments don't structure their curricula in a way that makes this easy
column4: but that's a department-specific problem. In any case
column5: I had no trouble taking a good lab-focused engineering class my freshmen year
column7: and it has worked out well in my personal experience.|~|4|~|Wednesday

column1: 62684|~|Christina Rice|~|I really appreciate and sympathy with this article
column2: it may be ambitious and some of the criticisms have merit. However
column3: I am a freshman who has just recently been comparing other engineering curriculum (as well as had the amazing opportunity to experience an engineering curriculum at my high school) and believe the idea of not including some exposure to your major is a flaw that should be addressed. In our first year at Princeton the engineering candidate's are not exposed to engineering but pure math and hard science
column4: while these are useful and tools we'll use for our duration here they are not our major; engineering is something distinctly different - it is design (or sometimes redesign) of structures
column7: etc. We have no exposure to the engineering/design process but our major will determine we do more that analyze or compute. I think it benefit our ability to start thinking about systems as changeable (something we can and will manipulate) and begin to actively reflect on how they work well and how they fall short. While still introducing us to the means by which we will do it with the current curriculum. At risk of offending some physics majors PHY 103/104 is engineering physics and the lab section is already experimenting with updating the lab due to certain shortfalls - we could change this into a design lab (which lends itself well to integration with a physics curriculum given we already have one lab - the AC motor - where we do a little design and it works). Also
column8: shifting some time were requirements could be scheduled might be an option that would not displace a humanities. Beyond this
column9: even if my ideas are imperfect (which they are) we are Princeton - to say something worthwhile
column10: like integrating engineering principles into our freshman teachings
column11: can not be done because a system we created can not be modified‚Ä¶while then we are not as good as engineering as we thought. We have bright minds here and together if this wanted to get done
column13: April 27

column1: 62684|~|Alum|~|Unexpectedly
column2: this article echoes my experience as a film producer.  My job especially starting out involved lots of non-theoretical networking
column6: and hustling in addition to all the artistic/intellectual things that initially attracted me.  I felt like I could do the non-theoretical stuff for about an hour a day before burning out whereas my ability to sit in the library and read and write was practically limitless.  That imbalance is partly a function of my personality
column7: but spending the most intensely focused part of my life at Princeton doing so much theory definitely pushed me further into etiolated nerdhood.|~|0|~|Thursday

One thing that would be interesting to see is if a more project oriented approach would improve the number of women who stay in or chose the BSE programs. Also
column5: I think clubs like Engineering without Borders would enable students to early on use their knowledge to help others.|~|0|~|Tuesday

column1: 62684|~|BSE_CS_14|~|Just have to say that if it wasn't for the the fact that I had worked on the "cool" practical side of software engineering before coming to Princeton

column5: which would have otherwise seemed irrelevant.|~|0|~|Friday

column1: 62684|~|Andrew Houck|~|The author‚Äôs main hypothesis ‚Äì that the structure of Princeton‚Äôs engineering curriculum biases students towards non-technical jobs ‚Äì is intriguing
column2: but does not seems to be born out by fact.  A cursory glance at career statistics for our peer institutions shows that their student career choices mirror our own (for instance
column3: 12% of MIT students go into finance
column4: 12% into consulting). A significant fraction of engineering students at all top schools pursue finance jobs
column5: not because they are bored of engineering
column6: but because they are highly sought-after
column9: enjoy the work and environment. Putting that aside
column10: many faculty empathize with the author‚Äôs desire for more hand-on learning in early stages of engineering education
column11: and this is reflected in ongoing changes brought about by SEAS
column13: and the various engineering departments. As departmental representative for ELE
column14: I am most familiar with the changes going on in electrical engineering.  We have always been quite strong at engaging students in faculty research
column15: but we want to make sure we do more than churn out faculty clones (though really
column16: can there ever be too many of me?).  As such
column17: one of our main strategic goals is to better serve students interested in more applied engineering. To this end
column18: we have recently revamped all of our required courses
column19: making sure that there is a significant lab component to get students hand-on experience starting in sophomore year. These are not typical one-off three-hour labs
column20: but rather ongoing projects throughout the semester where students build significant and complex systems
column21: learning fundamentals in a more applied way.  We have added sophomore level independent work courses
column22: so students can do independent work for credit starting in sophomore year.  We‚Äôve given students significantly more freedom in CarLab to pursue independent ideas.   We are supporting the hardware side of Hack Princeton in order to foster a culture of engineering outside the classroom.  We are now requiring a senior thesis
column23: and are working hard to make sure that this will be an amazing and defining experience.  We are encouraging students to pursue their own project ideas for their thesis
column24: including in groups and across departmental boundaries where appropriate
column25: and are matching them with faculty members who are excited to mentor students outside their main research area. We are also lucky enough to have generous alumni who enable incredible new initiatives.  Thanks to the Steve Johnson Slingshot Fund
column26: we can offer significant resources to ELE students to pursue entrepreneurial projects or truly unique internship opportunities ‚Äì we‚Äôve so far offered money for a group of students developing an Android-controlled power strip
column27: another building a new type of 3D touchscreen
column28: another creating a network of e-ink based campus posters
column29: and to send a student to NASA.  We‚Äôre also building ‚Äúnerd kits‚Äù for incoming students that include all of the hardware platforms they will use during their required courses
column30: as well as some cool sensors and actuators; they keep these throughout their time here
column31: so they always have access to a variety of new technologies
column32: lowering the bar for tinkering. In short
column33: although I‚Äôm not sure it will sway people‚Äôs career paths
column34: you‚Äôve touched on something very important to us
column35: and something that will significantly enhance our student‚Äôs educational experience. Princeton will never give up on teaching strong fundamentals ‚Äì the strength of our student‚Äôs on fundamentals is perhaps the most frequent compliment I hear from employers ‚Äì but that doesn‚Äôt mean we can‚Äôt also engage at a more applied level as well.|~|0|~|Thursday

column1: 61190|~|Not just merit|~|Look
column2: good for the kid. It sounds like he's smart and worked hard in high school and achieved a reasonable reward. His parents oughtta be proud. The reason this story has so much resonance is the All Eight headline. College applicants are told over and over again that it's a crapshoot
column3: that acceptance to Ivy-caliber schools is random at best even for the top academic achievers
column4: and that rejection happens randomly too. And there are plenty of anecdotal stories that bear that out
column5: about such-and-such a kid with the best scores who got rejected from Cornell or whatever. Under the holistic system
column6: no student can possibly fit the needs of EVERY school in any one year. With so much random churn in the process
column7: getting in to All Eight is a virtual impossibility for anyone - right? Apparently not. As long as you're a reasonably high-achieving black kid with a compelling family story
column8: the randomness doesn't apply. That's the implicit message of the story and why it has gotten so much traction. College admissions is emphatically NOT a meritocracy
column9: but many people believe that it is. Merit matters to some degree
column10: but so do other things. My numbers (2390
column11: 12 AP 5s
column12: etc etc) blew this kid's away
column13: but I certainly didn't get in everywhere I applied (Ivy or otherwise). I'm neither jealous of his choices nor apologizing for taking advantage of what I had to work with: my in at Princeton? Legacy. But it's time everyone recognized that merit is not the determining factor in college admissions that many people believe it to be.|~|19|~|Monday
column14: April 7

59558|~|'17|~|I think too many comments are focusing on the writer's art example. It's not just art--intro classes like COS 126 or Math 103 or LIN 201 are filled with people who already know the material. Even if grade deflation isn't a factor in the class, it is intimidating to fall behind while it seems like almost everyone else knows what he/she is doing. Also, courses become tougher to accommodate people with background knowledge leaving newcomers at a disadvantage. It is difficult to explore new academic fields at Princeton, and I'm glad this article addresses that.|~|12|~|Wednesday, March 26, 2014 1:34 PM|~|1303855713|~|NA|~|0
59558|~|'15|~|If you're not taking a course because everyone else seems better than you, then you're being close-minded and cowardly. It is precisely in these courses that you learn the most- about your own intellectual capacities, your learning habits, and your ability to accept difficulty. If you're worried about grading, have a conversation with your professor or preceptor. Be honest and tell them that you're new to the discipline, ask questions about assignments, even ask to submit drafts. Especially in visual arts courses, the instructors go about grading in a holistic sense, taking into account each student's own methods and level of engagement with the material. If you really show that you're thinking rigorously about the course, they're not going to care if you can't replicate a DaVinci.|~|7|~|Monday, March 24, 2014 8:30 PM|~|1300571534|~|NA|~|0

column2: I am a little older and therefore a little wiser. I graduated from college at age 21 and was married six weeks later to my childhood sweetheart - what I always wanted. We waited five and a half years to have five children

column7: and travelled every year before the babies came. Then we took up camping as a family

column10: who sucumb to the social imperative to have a spouse and often settle for the woman as much as she settles for him. But there is more. column12: a surrogate does. It can be a co-worker
column13: a tennis coach
column14: a bar tender. Any addiction
column15: controllable at age 21 is out of control at age 50
column16: whether it is alcohol
column17: drugs
column18: sex
column19: gambling or golf. We both know there are many others. When a spouse chooses the addiction over the partner
column20: the marriage becomes just a shell of its former self yet couples stay together for social

column1: 55738|~|student2|~|I second what was said before and respectfully suggest that if signing the petition of a USG candidate is so important to you that you can quit. The public is suspicious of media outlets generally
column2: sometimes with good reason and sometimes unjustifiably
column3: but there is no doubt that the bias of some causes collateral damage to even the "good" papers. What I think is the main premise of your paper
column4: that the Prince "has a responsibility to provide a well-rounded apprenticeship experience to its student journalists
column5: is demonstrably false. The Prince's first and foremost obligation is to its readership to report the news not only fairly and accurately but also without even the appearance of bias. This is why such statements as Schleifer is a former news editor for The Daily Princetonian" appear in articles and why news staffers are not permitted to make certain comments on Facebook and Twitter and endorse USG candidates. Imagine
column7: if the New York Times were to have Paul Krugman write "objective news" articles on Republicans in Congress and also his famously opinionated
column8: liberal-leaning editorials. He might technically have to be "objective" in his news reporting
column9: but no one would believe it
column10: and this lack of belief is just as important as actual bias on the part of a news staffer. Very poor decision to air what should be an internal issue publicly
column11: especially when there are procedures in place for initiating rules changes.|~|1|~|Friday

column1: 55738|~|student|~|To a newspaper
column2: nothing is more important than it's reputation - if a newspaper appears to have even an inkling of institutional bias
column3: it's reputation can be ruined. Think of how Fox News is viewed by liberals: nothing they say is taken seriously because it appears to have institutional bias. It's just too questionable and there are just too many potentials for crossover when a writer works for both Opinion
column4: in which they offer opinions about campus issues
column6: which reports objectively on those campus issues. What if Barack Obama was asked to report on the GOP National Convention? Once a person has publicly declared an opinion one way or another
column7: they can never report objectively on that issue
column10: there will always be detractors who find implicit bias. The Prince doesn't want to give those detractors even more to work with. So in providing that apprenticeship experience
column11: the Prince shouldn't necessarily work to give its writers a taste of what awaits them at Fox or at CNN or any other significantly biased news outlet. They should adopt the standard practices of respected news outlets - which includes keeping news
column13: and copy separate - so that students know what constitutes good journalism. They should provide students with an experience that elevates the quality of journalism when students go out into the field - they should teach students how to make good press. Marcelo's article had it's own issues of appearing to be biased against the University - which is just as bad as being biased for the University - but the general idea is that being an independent student newspaper means that the Prince's reputation should be that of complete independence and objectivity. The Prince has a reputation problem
column14: but this policy at least prevents them from exacerbating it.|~|1|~|Friday

column1: 54653|~|moobly|~|But there is no concrete standard for 'college level work'. In truth most US colleges teach an expanded high school level curriculum. For every Princeton there are several hundred minor schools that teach at a level to accommodate the students available to them. Your cautions have already come to pass. I think we need to recognize that the intellectual skills required by many skilled trades are actually above those currently required to achieve a college degree. In my experience
column2: as an engineer
column3: the technical knowledge and aptitude of a skilled plumber
column7: drafter etc. is typically better than that of your average college graduate
column8: even from related academic fields. IMO the distinction among these individuals arises primarily from their learning styles and interests. They are not less intelligent
column10: than your average college grad rather they approach education with a different orientation and motive. Whether Princetonians want to associate with them is irrelevant to me - I've learned to regard them as peers.|~|4|~|Monday
column11: February 10

column1: 54653|~|catorenasci|~|Perhaps there is no longer a concrete standard for college level work
column2: though it used to mean (at least as recently as the early 1960s
column3: more or less) the ability to learn a year or two's worth of calculus
column4: to read and understand text books written at an adult level as well as to read and understand the then generally agreed upon literary and philosophical canon
column5: and a fair command of Latin and one modern language (usually French or German).  While most (all
column6: one would hope) Princetonians could do this even today
column7: I would hazard a guess that at least half
column9: of today's "college" students could not.  And
column10: rarely are such demands placed upon undergraduates today
column11: even at elite colleges and universities. To your point that the skilled trades often required in the skilled trades are higher than those required to obtain a college degree today
column12: I cannot disagree. (I suspect it may even be possible to graduate Princeton today without taking many particularly rigorous courses.)  That this is true does reflect an actual
column13: not a theoretical decline  in academic rigor as another commentator pointed out. Before the Second World War
column14: when perhaps 10-15% of the population attended college and admission was primarily a matter of preparation and means
column15: it was certainly true that there might well be no difference in cognitive ability between a machinist or mechanic and a university trained engineer.   When more than half of the high school graduates go to college (of some sort)
column16: it is far less often (though not never) the case that the skilled tradesman has the same cognitive ability as the graduate of an elite college or university.  Sad
column17: in a way
column18: because many think the skilled and inventive tradesmen contributed far more to the building of our economy and national infrastructure than did the college graduates.  Yet
column19: not sad in another way
column20: because far fewer young men and women of real talent are unable to obtain a good college or university degree (but that at the same time the degree  is being devalued
column21: sigh!). I was perhaps clumsy in my last sentence
column22: and it certainly came out as elitist or what used to be called snobbish.  Indeed
column23: there are significant numbers of good university graduates who don't make those sorts of distinctions
column24: and it would be hard to argue that one should
column25: but nonetheless
column26: many more people still do make the distinctions. My larger point was that
column27: like it or not
column28: there really are class distinctions in this country
column29: and college is a widely understood class indicator.  I would suggest that it is very difficult today for a young person to be considered 'middle class' without a college degree (of whatever sort) and even more difficult to be 'upper-middle class' without what used to be called a "good" degree - an undergraduate or professional degree from an elite private college or university
column30: or a handful of the public flagships (Michigan
column32: Virginia
column33: Vermont
column34: and perhaps North Carolina and Texas).|~|1|~|Monday

column1: 53779|~|JHay|~|Thanks for this
column2: Kyle--I think you've raised some valid criticisms while being gracious enough to understand the good intent behind We Care Solar's mission.  As a returned Bridge Year student
column3: I feel many of the same frustrations about how international service is conceptualized and applied within the paradigm of "developed" helping "developing."  I agree with you on the dangers of each of your service sins
column4: and remember that avoiding sensationalism was one of my biggest goals going into Bridge Year. At the same time
column5: I realize that my own learning curve has included many of the same sentiments that now rub us both the wrong way.  I'm excited that this team will have the chance to meet with returned BYP-Peru students before they leave to learn a little more about Urubamba
column6: and perhaps change their frame of reference for their role in service.  Being aware of the dangers of sensationalism
column9: and simplification in service work is a good first step
column10: and one that can certainly be taken before leaving to go abroad
column11: so thanks for raising the issue--but I also think that it takes time and sometimes on-the-ground experience (paired with the proper humility and willingness to learn
column12: of course) to better understand these essential dynamics of service.  So I hope to read about these students' reflections after they've returned to see how their perspectives on service
column13: particularly international service
column14: have changed as a result. On a different note
column15: I'd recommend ANT 314 (anthropology of development) to Princeton students wanting to think through these issues a bit more; at least it was a helpful class for me in that regard.|~|11|~|Monday

column1: 53450|~|Really?|~|From the perspective of a couple decades beyond my acceptance letter and my baccalaureate graduation day
column2: I respectfully disagree with this premise of this column.  And I‚Äôm frankly a bit concerned about what seems to be a sense of an entitlement to be able to avoid ambiguity on important matters of life
column3: and would respectfully advise applicants (and Princeton students if this is a common perspective) to find  their spine on and start to grow up.  The ambiguity of being deferred to the ‚Äúregular‚Äù pool may be a little bit stressful for those who have worked hard
column5: and who may look at life outcomes as something within their own talents and will to control
column6: but welcome to life. Notwithstanding the talent and will that has brought you success to this point
column7: you‚Äôre going to have to face some ambiguity
column8: and some big time ambiguity.  Worrying for a couple of months about whether or not you are going to get into Princeton is not something that anyone should have to protect you from. You‚Äôre eighteen
column10: and in a few years you‚Äôll be launched into the world with the resources to become not only a well functioning adult but a leader.  Welcome to wondering if you‚Äôll get that job
column11: that apartment
column12: and into that graduate program.  Welcome to wondering if the start up you‚Äôve invested the last three years of your time and money in will fly or bomb.  Welcome to wondering if your old buddy from your college team is going to make it through his cancer.  Welcome to wondering if the last fertility treatment cycle you endured with your spouse results in a pregnancy
column13: or if its time to think about adoption.  Welcome to wondering at 3am  if the successful result of that pregnancy or adoption was one of the teenagers hurt or worse in the drunk-driver accident  after the prom.  If you are deferred and not rejected outright
column14: you know that you likely have a very good chance of getting into a very good school
column15: and you‚Äôre probably even good enough to find yourself some scholarship money somewhere.  If you‚Äôre deferred
column16: you‚Äôre left with worrying about whether or not you get into Princeton
column17: but probably not worrying about whether you‚Äôll be going to college at all
column18: or that you‚Äôre never going to walk
column19: or see again
column20: or see a loved one again.|~|3|~|Monday

column1: 52794|~|Hythlodaeus|~|In truth
column2: by providing relatively large reading loads to its students
column3: Princeton's professors do their students a rather great favor. Not only do these readings teach students a skill that is extraordinarily useful in an academic context and outside it - skimming - they also provide students with a breadth of reading and knowledge that benefits them in their other courses
column5: and in a variety of future endeavors. The Board's belief that under-prepared students are the cause of lackluster discussions would do themselves well by observing their precepts from the perspective of those who have led precepts. Students in precepts are generally not so much under-prepared as they are either unwilling or unable to process or discuss the material because of the stage of their academic and personal development. This is difficult for students
column6: but these are skills that they must learn with time
column7: not so much by transforming Princeton into a high school replete with daily quizzes and the hand-holding the Editorial Board would have us do in all things but instead by challenging students. By way of an example
column8: I point to that smug STEM-major who commented earlier who is clearly one of these less developed students
column9: reckoning that the length of lectures or number of quizzes determines the difficulty of a course
column10: unable to comprehend the concepts of mastery or creativity in his desperate and shortsighted pursuit of an A and
column11: ultimately
column12: a marginally lucrative career that he no doubt truly earned by a pitiful amount of rote memorization and "hard work." I for one eagerly await his upcoming self-congratulatory TEDx talk
column13: which will be as banal as any of his comments in a precept. But at least he works hard
column14: which is more than anyone can say for the Editorial Board of this periodical
column15: who will no doubt soon churn out yet another column about why they deserve more A-s than B+s. AH|~|9|~|Monday
